titleStmt.title: How social norms emerge: the interindividual actor-critic

affiliation.orgName: Edmond & Lily Safra Center for Brain Sciences

analytic.title: How social norms emerge: the interindividual actor-critic

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Social norms shape a vast range of human behaviors, from everyday interactions to major life choices. Yet, existing theories of norm emergence typically focus either on why certain norms arise (substantive properties) or on how they spread and persist (dynamical properties), often making conflicting assumptions. Here, we propose a unified account in which norms prescribing how one ought to act emerge naturally from the fundamental algorithms that guide individual learning-whether in social or non-social settings. Our account builds on recent advances in decision-making and emotion research that have highlighted 'actor-critic' models as a core mechanism of learning from feedback. We extend this mechanism to social settings by assuming that it is not only we who critique our actions, others critique our actions as well. By simulating this interindividual form of learning, we show that it uniquely produces group behavior that exhibits both substantive and dynamical properties of realworld social norms, including prosociality, ingroup bias, stickiness, self-reinforcement, and local conformity / global diversity. Our framework thus offers a uniquely parsimonious way to bridge the gap between individual learning and group behavior.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Human behavior is everywhere regulated by social norms that dictate actions in both mundane contexts (e.g., tipping) and major life decisions (e.g., choosing a life partner; Etcheverry & Agnew, 2004;Kohler et al., 2001). Many different accounts have been offered for how such norms emerge, but each has sought to explain different properties of norms, relying on varied and often contradictory assumptions (Gelfand et al., 2024). Here, we show how different properties of social norms that previously received different explanations can be coherently and parsimoniously explained, specifically by leveraging advances in research on how humans generally learn how to act, whether in social or non-social settings.

We focus on a class of algorithms-'actor-critic' reinforcement learning (Sutton & Barto, 2018)-that is proving increasingly useful for explaining how humans learn (Biderman & Shohamy, 2021;Biderman et al., 2023) and what role emotions and moods play in this regard (Bennett et al., 2022;Emanuel & Eldar, 2023). As implied by its name, an actor-critic agent is composed of two components: an actor that takes actions, and a critic that evaluates them. This compartmentalization makes it natural to convert actor-critic into an interindividual learning algorithm. All we need to assume is that agents do not only critique their own actions but also those of others. We thus propose a social adaptation of actor-critic learning.

As we will demonstrate, this interindividual learning model uniquely generates group behavior that exhibits key properties of human social norms, including prosociality, ingroup bias, stickiness, self-reinforcement, and local conformity / global diversity. The present work thus shows how a basic cognitive mechanism by which individuals learn from reinforcement offers a uniquely coherent and parsimonious account of the emergence of norms within social groups.

div.head: Overview
div.p: This work has three main aims. First, it aims to establish the need for a unified explanation of the emergence of social norms. Second, it aims to propose an interindividual adaptation of actor-critic learning for modeling group behavior. Thirdly, it aims to show that this model can account for well-established properties of human social norms.

Consequently, the paper is organized into three main sections. After defining the scope of the present work, the first section provides a brief overview of existing research on social norms, distinguishing between different kinds of accounts, and identifying the key properties each sought to explain. The second section presents the structure and basic behavior of the interindividual actor-critic model, and reviews evidence supporting its underlying assumptions. The third section then presents simulation results demonstrating how the interindividual actor-critic can coherently account for properties of norms that have so far received disparate, sometimes inconsistent explanations. Finally, the general discussion outlines future directions for empirical and theoretical research, including implementation of the model in more realistic network structures, and its integration with more advanced mechanisms of social cognition.

div.head: Scope of the present work
div.p: Most existing social norm research recognizes three types of norms: descriptive norms, prescriptive norms, and conventions (Bicchieri, 2006;Hawkins et al., 2019). Descriptive norms, such as fashions or customs, are behaviors that are prevalent within a community, but there is no obligation for people to follow them. Prescriptive norms, in contrast, are shared understandings about how people ought to act, specifying which actions are obligatory, permitted, or forbidden (Crawford & Ostrom, 1995). Violations of prescriptive norms are therefore often punished (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2004). Typical examples include not littering in public spaces, or helping someone in need. Finally, conventions are means for coordination, which ensure that different people have similar interpretations for a given action (e.g., the meaning of body language; Hawkins et al., 2019).

It has often been observed, however, that behaviors commonly classified as descriptive norms or conventions frequently exhibit a prescriptive aspect (Pezepiorka et al., 2022). For instance, driving on the right side of the road may appear merely as a coordination problem, but drivers expect others to comply with this convention, and violating this expectation entails severe penalties (Hawkins et al., 2019). Similarly, changing fashions are often referred to as descriptive norms, but not following them can violate peers' expectations and may get punished by exclusion.

Therefore, instead of adhering to the common categorization, we more precisely define the norms we aim to explain as group behaviors that are both prevalent and expected, in the sense that not following them is likely to induce retribution from others. Such group behaviors satisfy the criteria for normative regularities recently proposed by researchers of normative behavior in animals (Westra et al., 2024). In humans, they may best be thought of as precursors of prescriptive norms, since they include all the necessary ingredients for the emergence of a prescriptive norm but may not yet be explicitly represented as such.

A comprehensive explanation of such group behaviors necessitates a modeling framework that evaluates behaviors as good or bad to varying extents. Reinforcement learning is particularly well-suited for this task since it explicitly quantifies the goodness of a behavior as the amount of reward it leads to. Negative outcomes and costs can also be accounted for as negative rewards. However, the space of multi-agent reinforcement learning models is vast (Du et al., 2023). This means that almost any behavior can likely be explained by more than one model. To circumvent this problem, we restrict ourselves to a relatively simple form of reinforcement learning that is grounded in the cognitive science of learning (Biderman & Shohamy, 2021;Biderman et al., 2023) and emotion (Bennett et al., 2022;Emanuel & Eldar, 2023). This parsimonious modeling approach enables us to conduct multi-agent simulations while making few new assumptions, all of which we make explicit.
At the same time, the simplicity of our modeling approach means that we do not aim to capture every phenomenon that takes place at the micro-level of interpersonal interactions.

Studies of such interactions have revealed complexity that goes substantially beyond simple reinforcement learning. Various works established the involvement of planning and strategic adaptation of one's behavior according to estimates of others' values, goals, and likely behavior (e.g., Wu et al., 2022;Barnby et al., 2022). Bayesian inference in this regard is also thought to enable people to factor in uncertainty and prior knowledge concerning others (Devaine et al., 2014;FeldmanHall & Shenhav, 2019). Such advanced cognitions are readily incorporated in reinforcement learning, but how to apply them in multi-agent models is a difficult and important open question. In the discussion section, we describe several potential directions for combining such advanced functions with the simpler model we propose here.
At the macro-level of group behavior, however, we show that our simple model can already explain well-established properties of social norms that are not explained by existing multiagent models.

div.head: Dominant accounts of norm emergence
div.p: Explanations of how social norms come into being center around two areas of focus: their substance and their dynamics (Gelfand et al., 2024). Substantive accounts seek to explain why particular norms emerge and not others. A main focus in this regard has been to explain why norms tend to promote prosocial behavior, such as cooperation, altruism, fairness, equality, and punishing behaviors against non-complying others (House, 2018;Ostrom, 2000). These properties, it is thought, cannot entirely be explained by approaches such as cooperative game theory (Bullinger et al., 2024) that assume people only strive to maximize their self-interest (Fehr & Schutenberger, 2018). This is particularly evident in third-party punishment games where people incur costs to punish others for disadvantaging other players. Self-interest cannot explain this behavior because all players involved remain anonymous and there is no future interaction between the players. Therefore, the most common explanation for the substantive properties of norms relies on a combination of "norm psychology"our inherent inclination, from early childhood, to perceive and act according to what is considered right or wrong in our environmentand evolutionary forces, which make prosocial norms more prevalent over time due to their contribution to a group's survival (Sripada et al., 2005;Tomasello, 2018;House, 2018;Chudek & Henrich, 2011;Kimbrough & Vostroknov, 2016;Kelly & Davis, 2018;Bicchieri et al., 2021).

Dynamical approaches, meanwhile, investigate the processes that lead to the emergence, persistence, and fading of norms, regardless of what those norms are. This is of particular interest when there are multiple possible equilibria and no guaranteed agreement within groups, when the choice between actions is arbitrary (Baronchelli, 2018), and when environmental changes make a previously established norm maladaptive (Young, 2015, Gelfand et al., 2024. A key question in such cases is how society arrives at a particular consensus (Baronchelli, 2018). Although centralized institutions likely play a role (McCombs, 1997;Keans et al., 2009;Oliver, 1993), most accounts posit that consensus primarily evolves in a bottom-up manner, as a result of spontaneous interactions between group members (Garrod & Doherty, 1994;Boyd & Richerson;1992, Jones, 1984.

There are two prominent approaches to modeling such interindividual interactions. The first, evolutionary game theory, assumes that agents seek to maximize personal gains. It thus centers on modeling how an agent's utility function depends on the choices made by other group members (Young, 2015). The second type of approach, which includes contagion models (Moran, 1958;Clifford & Sudbury, 1973;Holly & Ligget, 1975;Bikhchandani et al., 1992) and social influence theory (Flasche et al., 2017), argues that consensus is driven by an inherent motivation to imitate others. Such models assume that any interaction between individuals drives their behaviors, preferences, or opinions closer together.

In sum, a multiplicity of accounts have been proposed to explain substantive and dynamical properties of social norms, yet a unified account is lacking (Gelfand et al., 2024). This is a problem for two reasons. The first is that each account only explains a subset of social norm properties, whereas combining the different accounts together results in inconsistencies that stem from their contradictory assumptions. Specifically, the idea of norm psychology that norms are held in place due to individuals' inherent motivation to adhere to prevalent norms is at odds with the claim of evolutionary and cooperative game theory that norms are held in place due to individuals' pursuit of self-interest. And neither of the former explanations is consistent with the idea that norms spread due to the motivation to imitate others.

The second reason we should strive for a unified account of social norms is the principle of parsimony. Occam's razor entails that in explaining a multifaceted phenomenon we should favor the simplest possible account, provided that it explains as many properties of the phenomenon as the more complicated, multiple-explanations account. For the same reason, we should also give priority to accounts whose key assumptions originate not in an attempt to explain the phenomenon in question, but in prior research that aimed to explain other independent phenomena. In this respect, accounts of group behavior that rely on basic cognitive science research offer a particularly promising avenue (Cushman & Gershman, 2019;Baek et al., 2021;FeldmanHall & Nassar, 2021;Hawkins et al., 2019;Hawkins et al., 2023). A model that relies on established findings about how people learn and make decisions could potentially require little to no new assumptions to explain the emergence of social norms. Here we use this approach to offer a parsimonious, unified explanation of the substantive and dynamical properties of social norms.

div.head: Properties of social norms
div.p: Having established the need for a unified explanation of social norms, we next review the key properties of norms that need to be explained. Building on prior work, we identify two substantive (prosociality, ingroup bias) and three dynamical (stickiness, self-reinforcement, local conformity / global diversity) properties. Below we describe the empirical evidence establishing each of these properties as fundamental to social norms.

div.head: Prosociality
div.p: Norms that foster prosocial behavior have emerged many times in human history (House et al., 2020;Curry et al., 2019;House et al., 2013;Rochat et al., 2009). Prosocial behavior is also widely evident in controlled experiments employing social decision tasks. In such tasks, people often choose to cooperate in situations where selfish agents would choose to free ride (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2003;Fehr & Gachter, 2000). This finding has been corroborated in 15 different populations tested across four continents (Henrich et al., 2006). Notably, prosocial norms vary across populations-one community may prioritize recycling over tithing, while another may do the reverse (Henrich & Muthukrishna, 2021). And also within a given population, careful analysis shows that no single norm can fully explain all prosocial behavior (Fehr & Schurtenberger, 2018), indicating that multiple prosocial norms must be involved. This is not to say that any individual norm must be prosocial, but the ubiquity and diversity of prosocial norms entails that an explanation of how social norms emerge must give weight to prosocial motivations.

div.head: Ingroup favoritism
div.p: Prosocial behavior does not benefit everyone equally. A meta-analysis of 168 studies shows that people often predominantly benefit others whom they consider a part of their group (Balliet et al., 2014). Evidence that such ingroup favoritism is driven by social norms has been found across observational and causal studies, in both naturalistic intergroup contexts and minimal group paradigms where strangers are arbitrarily assigned into groups (Iacoviello & Spears, 2018;Iacoviello et al., 2017). Some have taken these findings as evidence for a generic norm that one's group should be favored (Sparks et al., 2017), but how such a norm emerges remains unclear (Dunham, 2018). Most importantly, such a generic norm does not explain why ingroup favoritism vanishes when the potential for within-group reciprocity is denied (Dunham, 2018;Jin et al., 1996;Yamagishi & Mifune, 2009). Nor can it explain the great diversity that exists in ingroup favoritism across different types of behaviors and contexts (Spears, 2021). A more compelling assumption is thus that the mechanisms by which prosocial norms emerge give greater weight to the benefit of people with whom one more frequently interacts, or at least expects to interact.

div.head: Stickiness
div.p: An important property distinguishing established norms from behaviors that are merely prevalent, is that people tend to stick to them even when they seem disadvantageous or arbitrary (Horne & Mollborn, 2020). This has been shown in both field (Welsch, 2022;Schneider & van der Linden, 2023) and laboratory (Pryor et al., 2019) studies. In the lab, for instance, people continue to stick to a prosocial norm that was induced by a tax even after the tax is removed (Farrow & Romaniuc, 2019). In real-world settings, multiple occurrences have been documented where societies adopted a norm of medical distrust due to mistreatment, and persisted in their distrust long after it was advantageous to do so despite costs to their health (Gelfand et al., 2024;Lowes & Montero, 2021;Ramos-Toro, 2023;Alsan & Wanamaker, 2018;Martinez-Bravo & Steggman, 2022).

Stickiness is important because groups might adopt norms that initially seem advantageous but are later found out to be disadvantageous. This could happen, for instance, because certain courses of action were initially more salient, easier to implement, or had clearer outcomes. Assessments of benefits and costs can also change with time, whether due to objective changes to the environment or due to newly gained knowledge. Indeed, the harms of second-hand smoking were unknown when public smoking first became widespread. The critical question, then, is why it took so many years for smoking in public spaces to become unacceptable even after the harms to non-smokers were revealed (Nyborg & Rege, 2003;Cummings & Proctor, 2014). Put more generally, the question of stickiness is why established norms tend to persist in conditions in which they would not have arisen in the first place.

div.head: Self-reinforcement
div.p: When a new norm starts to emerge, the more people follow it, the more people are compelled to follow it (Young, 2015). That is why societal changefor example, in attitudes towards smoking, same-sex marriage, marijuana use, and even footbindingtends to spread rapidly once it initiates (Tribou & Collins, 2015;Mackie, 1996). Similarly, empirical work concerning climate change shows that people are more likely to adopt environmentally friendly practices if many others adopt them (Welsch, 2022). And lab experiments show that people align their preferences in accordance with arbitrary norms manipulated by the experimenters (Pryor et al., 2019), with rapid change occurring once support for a new norm among group members reaches a critical threshold (Centola et al., 2018). Although the mechanism behind this 'tipping point' phenomenon is yet unclear (Andrighetto & Vriens, 2022), the S-shaped curve it typically follows (Rogers, 1962) is most consistent with acceleration due to self-reinforcement.

div.head: Local conformity / global diversity
div.p: Another well-established property of social norms is their tendency to produce uniformity of behavior within groups, but diversity across groups (Young, 2015). This is true not only for conventions like language (Hawkins et al., 2019) but also for norms that prescribe value judgments and economic preferences (Young & Burke, 2001). A particularly well-studied example of this property manifests in crop-sharing agreements, whereby a landlord leases land to a farmer in exchange for a fixed share of the crops. Field studies reveal that the landlord's share remains similar across contracts within a local community, but differs widely across communities. Although local economic factors like soil quality systematically influence the landlord's share, such factors do not offer a sufficient explanation for the observed uniformity within communities, nor for the sharp changes between them. This observation has led to the conclusion that social norms are paramount in dictating the proportion of crops given to landlords. That these norms tend to be locally uniform but globally diverse suggests that they are shaped by repeated social interactions.

div.head: The interindividual actor-critic model
div.p: As we have seen, one common ground across most accounts of social norms is the idea that norms emerge from repeated interactions among group members. Presumably, people learn from these interactions how they ought to act in different situations. To model this process, we thus turn to the basic cognitive science of learning, and consult the algorithms by which people learn how they ought to act, whether in social or non-social settings. Such algorithms are most often specified using the general framework of reinforcement learning (Barto, 1994;Montague, Dayan, Person, & Sejnowski, 1995;Schultz, Dayan, & Montague, 1997;Daw, Niv, & Dayan, 2005;Niv, 2009). Following a brief description of the reinforcement-learning framework, we will focus on a popular reinforcement-learning algorithm that is increasingly supported by a wide range of studies on learning, decisionmaking, and emotions, and that is highly suitable for modeling interindividual learningthe advantage actor-critic model.

div.head: The basics of reinforcement learning
div.p: Reinforcement learning is a computational framework that describes how an agent can learn from experience to maximize its expected cumulative reward (Sutton & Barto, 2018). A reinforcement learning problem is typically specified as a Markov Decision Process, which consists of a set of states the agent may occupy (denoted ), a set of actions it may take in each state (denoted ), and scalar rewards (denoted ) that are associated with different states and actions. By sampling different actions and learning from their outcomes, a reinforcement learning agent updates its action-selection policy (denoted , the probability of taking different actions in each state) so as to reach states and perform actions that are associated with high expected cumulative reward. The expected cumulative reward associated with visiting a particular state is defined as the value of that state ( ):

where 0 < ≤ 1 serves to discount rewards that are farther in time. Similarly, the expected cumulative reward associated with taking a particular action in a particular state is defined as the value of that action ( ):
Values of states and actions share a close correspondence with one another since the former equals a weighted sum of latter:

with weights determined by the probability of taking each possible action from the present state, given the agent's action-selection policy. This correspondence also manifests in a reexpression of the value of an action as a sum of its immediate reward and the discounted value of the state to which it leads, +1 (Bellman, 1957):
Actor-Critic learning

The advantage actor-critic, sometimes referred to more simply as actor-critic (Sutton & Barto, 2018), is one of the most commonly used reinforcement-learning algorithms. Within machine learning, various versions of this algorithm have reached impressive performance in complex tasks (Mnih et al., 2016;Wang et al., 2016Wang et al., , 2017. In neuroscience, it has helped differentiate the roles of two neural populations in the basal ganglia, one serving as actor and the other as critic (Kaplan et al., 2020;O'Doherty et al., 2004). And in cognitive science, it has most recently come to the fore due to its ability to explain how humans learn and make decisions (Biderman & Shohamy, 2021;Biderman et al., 2023), as well as what role emotions and moods play in this regard (Bennett at al., 2022;Emanuel & Eldar, 2023). Before reviewing this evidence, we briefly describe a simple version of this algorithm.

An actor-critic agent is composed of two components: an 'actor' that chooses actions, and a 'critic' that evaluates them ( Figure 1A). Each time step, the actor chooses an action according to the agent's policy. The critic then observes the outcome and accordingly evaluates the action. Finally, the critic transmits its evaluation to the actor, which updates the policy accordingly.

Importantly, the critic's evaluation consists of an estimate of the 'advantage' (denoted ) that the chosen action conferred over and above what was expected from the state in which the action was taken:
which, given Eq. 4, can be estimated as the temporal difference error:
Thus, in addition to updating the policy, the estimated advantage also serves to update state value estimations:

Given the correspondence between values of actions and states (Eq. 3), advantage can be shown to capture the difference between the values of chosen ( ) and unchosen (̃) actions (Bennett et al., 2022):

≠ A positive advantage means that the chosen action's value exceeds the value of alternative actions represented in the policy, whereas a negative advantage means that there are other, more desirable actions. In both cases, a rational agent should strive to eliminate advantageby eliminating other actions from the policy in the former case, and eliminating the chosen action in the latter case. Hence, the actor will increase or decrease its propensity to take the chosen action according to the sign of the advantage computed by the critic.
This adaptation of the policy is achieved by updating policy parameters using stochastic gradient descent (Williams, 1992):
